There's a very coo, and simple experiment we did when I was in 7th or 8th grade that demonstrates that your body isn't really directly measuring temperature.

Stick one hand in a water bath of warm water, stick the other hand in a water bath of cold water.

Now, stick both hands in a bath of luke-warm water.

The hand that was in hot water will feel like the water is very cold, since it's now cooling down. The hand in cold water will feel like the water is very warm, since it's now heating up.

It's a VERY weird feeling getting these two completely contradictory signals from the same thing. But it instantly tells you that your body isn't really doing what you think it is, and your perceptions of reality aren't necessarily accurate.

Cool stuff. Yes, it is the heat conductivity - or heat flow. I really got a dose of this in my few years doing R&D. The plastic is a thermal/heat insulator, and so is the paper in the book. Metals tend to have over ten times the heat flow conducted.

Real world: For one experiment, I was looking for the best insulator I could find for use in some tooling, to keep hot oil heat energy away from cooling water channels. I ended up with a strange plastic called Polybenzimidazole, used in rockets' nose cones and in firefighter clothing. It took two days in an electric furnace to get it up to 450°F. When I took it out, I knew intellectually that I could pick it up and not get burned. But I almost didn't test it. I was freaking out. When I did, I did not get burned. It STILL read 450°F. It felt room temperature to me.

Years earlier, I worked for Ferro Corporation. I had a nice company brochure, and in it was a photo of a guy holding a SPACE SHUTTLE TILE in his bare hand, A glowing red hot space shuttle tile. Space shuttle tiles, their purpose is to NOT let heat flow into the metal of the shuttle. They do a great job of it. When they are knocked off, it ain't pretty.

Temperature is NOT what burns you. It is the heat flow. The thermal conductivity. The heat energy cannot hurt you if it is not able to flow into your skin. Stopping the flow is stipping the burn.

Polybenzimidazole, BTW, does not burn, and it does not melt.

I think it's not true that our skin doesn't sense temperature. Skin feels colder temperature touching a 19deg aluminium block because it actually cools down (I guess 21deg) almost immediately due to 3 main factors: Aluminium high density, high thermal conductivity and high specific heat capacity. Skin feels warmer temperature touching a 19deg plastic block because it barely cools down (perhaps 30deg) and the block locally warms up almost immediately in the contact area to similar temperature due to same factors: low density, low thermal conductivity. So yes skin actually senses it's own local temperature.

I also have a small item about semantics. People talk about "heat being transferred" or "heat being conducted" or "something has heat". I had a professor that would slap our wrists (you tell me if he's correct). He argued that heat is not a thing, rather it is a process. It is the process of moving "thermal energy". As it is not a thing, you cannot transfer it or posses it. You can heat a cup of coffee, but the cup of coffee does not have heat (rather it has thermal energy).

It's actually a three-way story between mass, heat capacity, and conductivity. If you took a -10c ice cube, and a piece of iron of equal weight and temperature, people would probably say that the ice is colder. Even though the iron would absorb your heat quicker, the ice would take about 5 times as much heat to equalize temperature between itself and your hand, and the melted water would take about 10 times as much as the iron.
Conductivity,  my dear Watson.

.I can make the case that this explanation is not correct.
It is true the aluminum has a better thermal conductivity. Being colder than your hands, aluminum does conduct heat away more quickly which means the surface of the aluminum does not come up to your fingers temperature and therefore, it cools your finger down and you're feeling the block's colder temperature on your fingers.
.
For the plastic or the book, since those materials conduct heat less, they do not retain their surface temperature, but the heat from your finger warms the surface up closer to the temperature of your finger. So you feel that it is warmer.
.
Therefore, while the conductivity explanation is true, you are actually feeling the surface temperature. The aluminum block prevents your finger from warming the surface whereas the other materials allow your finger to warm up the surface. Therefore you are actually feeling the temperature.
.

Incidentally, this is why fans help us feel cooler when in a hot room. The fan doesn't cool the air temperature at all. In fact, the mechanical energy introduced by the fan motor is converted to kinetic energy of the air and heat produced by friction that actually warms the air by an imperceptible amount. It's the moving air against our skin that helps increase the rate of heat transfer away from our skin surface, thus giving the sensation of us feeling cooler.

Explanation at the end is not quite accurate. When touching something you don't feel the 'rate at which heat is conducted' but you feel the 'surface temperature'. A material which has low thermal conductivity can not transport the heat from your hand very quickly, which results in a higher surface temperature (momentarily). A material with high conductivity will transport the heat from your hand quicker so it is constantly 'cooling' the surface, resulting in a lower surface temperature.

It's sad to see just how dumb most people are. Things I figured out when I was 3 yrs old. Also his simplistic breakdown is inherently false. It's not just thermal conductivity. The specific heat capacity of the object needs to be accounted for. Along with the thermal conductivity, (latent heat) for ice. A total of 334 J of energy are required to melt 1 g of ice at 0°C, which is called the latent heat of melting. The temperature in the environment need to be addressed as the Aluminum will feel hotter once it's above your hands temperature.

If those objects were (temperature stable) on a hot 115 Degree day. The aluminum would feel hotter than the book. (reverse of this experiment). On a cold day, If he was using a piece of silica aerogel for a super insulator and it was coated with a thin sheet of aluminum. It could still feel colder than the plastic but the total specific heat capacity would be so low and the low thermal conductivity of the aerogel super insulator that it would not get far melting the ice and the plastic could melt the ice faster. This is due to the "total" combined specific heat capacity being so low and the energy required to melt the ice. That is the latent heat, physical (phase) change from ice to water. 

This is also why stainless steel or aluminum door freezers has to be on the "very" thin side. If they increased the thickness when you touch it at -10 to -30C. Your hand would get very stuck and you would have to rip the skin off trying to get free so you don't get almost instant frostbite. Too thick and even water won't free you. Thermal conductivity comes from electrons carrying heat and anharmonicity of phonons (i.e. phonons scattering from one another), while heat capacity comes from mostly the harmonic content of the phonons. (Ignoring cryogenic conditions).

You are not precisely correct that what you feel is the rate of conductivity. Your body has more than one nerve system for pain. The myelensted neurons (wrapped in a myelin) transmit quickly, but your brain interprets the info logically (e.g., God dammit, I'm so clumsy, why did I stub my to again). The unmyelenated nerves transmit veeeeery slowly. That slow, pulsing, miserable pain is activity in a different part of your brain. It takes so long to emerge because that's literally how long unmyelenated signals take to travel from your toe to your brain.

Touch and feel are a fascinating topic, especially because we all don't realize how little we understand about these most familiar experiences.

It would have be nice to add:   Your brain does not actually feel the object, your brain only feels your skin (that is all the brain is connected to).  The aluminum (being conductive) receives more heat from the skin because the heat that goes into the aluminum quickly transfers to the other aluminum atoms leaving "room" for more heat to enter.  The plastic, however, being less conductive takes the heat from the hand, but the heat mostly stays right there with the surface atoms of the plastic.  They quickly fill with heat and become the same temperature as the hand so heat stops moving out of the hand.   FYI:  if you were to check the temperature of the plastic and metal, after the hand interaction, you would notice that the plastic is warmer (surface atoms),  But if you check 5 minutes later you would notice that the metal is warmer (having actually absorbed more heat from the hand.)  Also the metal has a lower specific heat, meaning a little bit of energy can cause a greater change in temp.   Even if both blocks absorb the same amount of heat, the aluminum will gain much more temperature.

Heat your oven to 150 degree Celsius (~300 Fahrenheit), put some cotton wool into that oven and let it rest there for half an hour. There is no way this cotton wool won't have the temperature of the oven after half an hour, so it must be 150/300 degree. Remove it from the oven using your plain hand. Don't worry, you won't get burned. To get burned, something you touch needs to heat up your skin to at least 45 degree Celsius (~113) Fahrenheit) and to do so, it must transfer a certain amount of heat energy to your skin. Of course, the hotter an object is, the more heat energy it has and the more heat energy it will be able to transfer on touch but that's not the only important factor here. The transfer speed is also limited by other material properties and if it cannot transfer heat faster than your body can transfer it away from your skin, it cannot heat up your skin at all, no matter how hot it is. The NASA developed a material to be used as heat isolator in space ships, which is such a bad heat conductor, you can heat up until it glows yellow, like a very hot iron and still touch it with your bare hand without getting burned.

Close, but wrong. You feel the temperature difference of your body, and the part of the heat sensing nervs in your hand. And because the aluminum cools your hand faster, achieving a greater temperature difference in a short time, you feel this difference immediately. The book or the plastic is conducting the heat so slowly, that your blood circulation heats your hand and the heat sensing nervs within, and probably the book itself faster, so you don't feel it cold at all. So the nerves do feel the heat, however not not an absolut heat, but a relative heat, because your brain continuously compares it with your body temperature. Not the heat conducting ratio is what you feel, but that is what is causing you to feel different temperature of two objects with same temperature, made from different materials with different heat conducting properties.
Try measuring the temperature of your hands immediately after holding for a minute the book or the aluminum, you'll see the temperature difference between the two measurements, and that is what you feel. Your hands are going colder from the aluminum.

You're talking about heat flow, not heat conductivity. Aluminum have a thermal conductivity of some 130 W/(m.K) at 25ºC and about 140 at 100ºC if i'm not mistaken so, roughly the same but still the feel the difference of aluminum at 25ºC and 100ºC because the heat flow will be much higher at 100ºC. Also I think it's really a misconception of saying we can feel temperature but also we can't feel heat conductivity (flow) also because our sensory system has evolved to serve as a defense mechanism and not just a "thermometer" or so for our convenience. So, the sensation given to us will depend of many factors like temperature (absolute/relative), heat flow, correlated to our own internal/external body temperature and others like if we're having a fever, our organs condition, health state, age, etc... So, in my opinion it's a misconception that we feel temperature but the explanation of what it is is not that simple either.

the rate heat transfers to or from an item.

the colder things are absorbing heat faster from the skin than those slightly warmer things.
if the item is colder than the skin it feels cold and the same with warmer than the skin feeling warmer; this is the direction of the flow of heat.
We detect the differential and flow of heat. not an actual temperature.

I feel like its important to note that you can feel temperature, I mean think about it. Hot water vs room temperature water, its something you can feel. No appreciable change in specific heats between these two either, so its not an intrinsic conductivity change between the two different waters that allows you to feel the temperature. Heat is a function of temperature difference as well as conductivity of the material, so you can tell the difference in temperature via how much more extreme the temperature is from our "normal" sense of temperature. However, in the real world, this would only be important to know when you have the same material and there is active heating or cooling occuring. But since humans interact with such a large variety of materials throughout their days (and mostly at room temperature), the phenomenon demonstrated in this video tends to be more applicable to daily life. Just thought it would be good to mention that our intuition isn't entirely wrong :)

"When you touch something, you don't actually feel temperature, you feel the rate at which heat is conducted either towards or away from you."

This is a bad explanation. It would be more correct, complete and intuitive to say that you feel the temperature not of the object that you're touching, but of your skin. After all, the heat sensitive cells are in your skin, not the object. An object colder than your skin (e.g. at room temperature) will cool your skin faster the more thermally conductive it is. Similarly, an object hotter than you will heat your skin faster if it's more conductive (e.g. compare metal handles vs plastic handles on a pan, the metal one will easily burn you if it has been on the fire for a while).

Note that all of the above applies to air too, not just solid objects. If you touch an object at water's boiling temperature, you will get burned in a fraction of a second, but you can put your hand in the oven even at temperatures much higher than that. this is because air is far less thermally conductive than solids.

Some people find it strange to realize that there is no such thing as "cold". The sensation we call cold is just the feeling of heat escaping from you faster.

And then you have stupid flat-earthers claiming that the moon produces its own light instead of reflecting it from the sun, because "moonlight is cold". The temperature in direct moonlight is lower than in the shade. They fail to realize that the object giving shade is keeping the heat from escaping as fast, so the temperature in shade is warmer. It's the same reason we wear hats and coats. Not to keep "cold" out, but to keep heat in.

It's just the conduction of the material which makes it "feel" a certain way. At the same temperature, an object at a lower temperature than body temperature will feel "colder" than another object, with lower thermal conductivity. It's why a pool feels colder than air even though they're the same temperature (assuming pool is not artificially heated).

When you touch something you don't feel the rate of transfer, you feel the temperature - but it's not the object's temperature, it's your hand's temperature (as that's where the temperature receptors in your skin are located). A cold object with high conductivity will cool your hand faster, that's why it feels colder.

But what you feel is the temperature, not the rate of change.

So to boil it down (haha), if something is warmer than your hand, it will feel even warmer if it has astonishing thermal conductivity and you will feel nothing if it has a non-existent thermal conductivity.
And if something is cold, a lower thermal conductivity will make it feel less cold and a higher thermal conductivity will make it feel colder.
To put it in a neat phrase, thermal conductivity exaggerates the difference.


As a sidenote, it is important to take the thermal conductivity of both objects that are coming into contact.

With the balls dropping, technically if you were to measure it scientifically with very accurate equipment you would find the heavier ball hits a fraction of a second faster. This is because of the force of air resistance acting on both balls as they fall through the air. The heavier ball has a higher terminal velocity shown by this equation: v = the square root of ((2*m*g)/(ρ*A*C)). https://www.wikihow.com/Calculate-Terminal-Velocity for more info. In this example all variables are practically the same except for the mass of the balls, therefore the heavier one hits first. At the height that the balls are dropped in this example the force of air resistance is almost negligible because there isn't enough time for it to slow down the balls enough to make much of a difference. However, if you drop the balls in a vacuum like on the surface of the moon they would land at the same time regardless of the height. You can even drop a feather and a bowling ball in a vacuum and they will hit at the same time since there is no air resistance. Love the videos, but technically, by milliseconds the heavier one hits first if they are about the same shape.

Iunno, I would have explained this in easy words to begin with instead of dropping the bomb. Aluminium moves heat faster than plastic. Both are colder than you, so aluminium cools your hand down fast, so your nerves say: Wow, that's cold. The ice is colder, so both plates heat it, but aluminium heats it faster, so it melts. The book doesn't move heat fast, so you think it's the same temperature as your body, because there is no fast change in temperature. Books would make good insulation material if you ever got stuck in a library during an apocalypse. The effect of moving heat is called thermal conductivity, because heat (thermos) is being conducted (moved). Here's some more interesting facts and words. Thank you for your time.

People tend to shut down when they think they're not smart enough. That's the whole thing with science in the public eye. The brain is efficient, so it will just divert its resources to something doable instead. People need to be made aware of how good they are at understanding things by avoiding specific terms and phrasing stuff in a more generally understandable way. Not as in "dumb things down" but as in "ease people into stuff".

Here, holding stuff and saying which feels colder, then proving there's no difference with a thermometer is perfect. People get confused in a positive way as their brains try to figure out what's happening and why their perception of the world does not align with reality. The brain is struggling to get that "Ahh" effect that happens when they understand that heat flows away from their hand and their senses are not absolute measuring devices. The moment that explanation drops wiki style, they lose that drive.

I remember that Millionnaire show candidate who totally shut down at an easy maths question. Her brain just never even started to think about that ridiculously trivial question. It was numbers, so she knew she wasn't good, so she spent all her time blabbing about how much she sucked at maths, instead of just looking at the problem and trying not to solve, but to understand it. That's the first step. Read the language. Figure out what the question is. It was disappointing because I believe she would've solved it if she had tried to. People underestimate their power. Everything is considered magic because it looks so strange. Make people get there by themselves. Show them that it's understandable, relatable, and that they can do it.

YOu don't really feel the rate of heatflow though. You feel the temperature of your skin and since your body generates heat by itself, thermal conductivity will establish an equilibrium temperature which is different with objects that conduct heat differently. Good conductors establish a lower equilibrium.

Compare this with a bucket with a little hole in it. If you pour water in it with some rate F, the waterlevel in the bucket will go up and the water will flow out through the tiny hole with flow rate G, initially the flow rate G < F which means that the bucket will start to fill up. But as the bucket fills up, the pressure on the water is greater and G becomes larger until G=F. This happens when there is a sufficient amount of water in the bucket so that the pressure causes G to be equal to F. Similar to the body, the metabolism can add heat to the skin. Depending on how large the flow of heat away from the body is, the equilibrium temperature of the skin will be higher. Similar to how that same experiment with a larger hole will have a lower equilibrium water level.
What I get out of this video is just how oblivious people are to what should be common sense.

Mechanical engineer here. The objects are at the same temperature. However, metal has a higher thermal conductivity which allows the heat to transfer from a person's hand to the object at a faster rate. This means that your body is losing heat faster when touching the metal object which is interpreted as the object being colder when in actual fact they are at the same temperature. The inverse is also true: when he puts the ice on the blocks the metal again has a higher thermal conductivity than plastic which results in heat transferring to the ice faster than that of the plastic. The result is that the ice melts faster on the metal than on the plastic.

"So when you touch something, you don't actually feel temperature. You feel the rate at which heat is conducted."
Not true, the surface of a poor thermal conductor gets close to the temperature of your skin quicker than nerves in your skin cool down. You do feel the temperature, it's just that by the time your nerves register the temperature of the surface of a poor conductor it's already been heated up by contact with your skin. Good conductors on the other hand remain fairly homogeneous throughout, and will draw the heat out of your skin and the nerves embedded within it.

What is happening is your internal body heat and circulation have warmed your fingertips to something approaching 37 degrees C, which feels "normal room temperature" to you. When you touch anything at air temperature (around 20 C) heat flows from the fingertips to the object, lowering the fingertip temperature enough to fire the cold detecting neurons, so they both feel cold to you. But the metal one conducts heat away faster (and has more capacity to "stre" it in), so more heat is drawn away from your fingertips than happens with the book. Your fingertips actually get colder with the aluminum.

Pretend instead of room temperature they have both been out all night at 0C When you touch the wood, it feels cold, but manageable. When you touch the aluminum block, the heat moves to the block to such a degree that the fingertips might actually freeze to the block, causing a "frostbite". And again, suppose both have spent 5 minutes sitting on an electric burner. They'll both be hot, but the aluminum can deposit heat faster into the fingertips, heating them to burning, while the wood can be touched briefly without burns (presuming its not actually on fire). That's the essence of the fire-walker's trick.

A very slight clarification: I've learned that the sensation of cold upon contact with a metal is indeed caused by the high thermal conductivity of the metal, but the sensation is not caused by heat leaving the body per se; the "direction" of heat flow into or out of the body is not detected by the thermoreceptors in the skin. Rather, the high heat conductivity of the metal does indeed remove heat quickly, and this lowers the temperature of the tissue around the receptor, and it is this lowering temperature that causes the receptors to fire. In other words, your fingers are getting colder; the local environment of the receptor isn't specifically sensitive to the direction of heat flow itself. This is only true if your skin temperature is higher than the temperature of the metal, of course. If I was taught incorrectly about this, I'd love to be enlightened!

actually this is not a question that have an easy answer, it have to do with how objects at different temperature behave when they are brough together (note that time is required for them to be in thermal equilibrium ,and usually that is not the case in the video) ,in fact you could prove with some clever math that the temperature at the surface where the two object with different temperature meet stays the same as heat is transferred from one object to another ,and that temperature have to do with the  ratio of thermal conductivity ( how easily a material allow heat to flow through it ) of the two object ,and since metal is more thermally conductive than paper ,therefore it can be shown mathematically that at the interface between the two object the temperature is lower ,since our body's temperature sensor neither detect our own body temperature nor the temperature of the object we came into contact with ,but rather the temperature near the surface of our skin where the nerve endings that detect temperature changes are located ,it will make us fill that metal are cooler

I was laughing at this video the whole time (no offense to anyone who didn't get it). It's not the actual temperature, it's how well the material conducts heat. Aluminum (or aluminium) steals the heat from your hand much better than plastic, so your hand feels cold. This is also why metal can feel so hot when in the sun, and why the ice melted faster on the aluminum block. The heat flows more freely into the object, either your hand on the metal or the ice.

Because metals are usually a lot better at transporting heat away from or to whatever they touch, since they are conductors instead of insulators. So the metal stays the same temperature as the environment but feels colder to the touch because it draws energy away from the hotter skin that's touching it, and redistributing that heat over a larger area so that it can very easily radiate into the air. If you'd painted the metal black it would actually do this even better, except probably not enough to change its temperature from the environment.

The final sentence is not really accurate.
When you touch an object you do feel temperature, but it is the temperature of the hypodermis where the thermal receptors are located. This inner temperature depends both on the temperature and the thermal conductivity of the external object.
So what you really feel is the combined effect of the temperature and the thermal conductivity of the object.

Simple experience to demonstrate that : take a half-full bottle of water and hold it by the empty side, feel warmer quickly
Now flip it upside down so the water comes to the part you're holding, it feels cold all of a sudden ^^

To make this explanation better, it's important to note that the humans are at a higher Temp. than the blocks, and the ice is at a lower temperature.  So the Al takes energy (not heat) away from the people faster which they perceive as cold.  The ice is colder, so the Al transfers energy to the ice faster than the plastic.  If the Al/plastic blocks were above human temperature by a significant amount, the aluminum would feel hotter than the plastic.  Temperature is really about how fast particles are moving, whereas heat is how particles collide between two substances.  Heat is relative and T is not.

I feel like none of these people really understood the explanation because none of them are familiar with the phrase "thermal conductivity." I think it would have been better to say that because your hand is warm and the object is cold, both objects sap heat away from your body as your hands gradually warm them, which is really what makes them feel cold to you. Essentially it's really only things that make you physically colder that feel cold to you. The reason then that the aluminum feels colder to you is because the aluminum is better at absorbing thermal energy (heat), which means that it draws the heat away from your hand and makes you colder faster than the plastic. Just saying "it's because of thermal conductivity" doesn't explain anything, and really just serves to further exemplify physics as this complicated thing as this complicated thing that normal will never be able to understand.

There's also a pretty biological explanation to this. Sensitive neurons get stimulated by a variation on temperature, but they doesn't "feel" external temperature but the inner part of the skin. So, if your skin changes temperature faster because it comes in contact with a better thermoconductor, neurons will be more stimulated. That's why aluminium "feels" colder than plastic.

P1. Yes. I am afraid you missed the point of the video entirely.

Thermal equilibrium via conductivity had already taken place by the time Derek had begun the poll. The objects had stabilised to outdoor ambient conditions as "they have both been outside for a while".  Both objects were basically at the same temperature, apart from the tiny amount of extra radiant heat the book was absorbing from the black cover.  The added heat is minuscule but the flow remains constant while the sun is shining.

P2. In the video, conductivity came into play when passersby are asked to compare the temperatures of the objects. Because we can only perceive heat flow and not temperature, the hard drive felt cooler than the book because the heat flow from the objects to the fingertips transferred at different rates.

You could certainly argue that my pointing out the temperature difference is pedantic, as it is almost negligible and irrelevant to the lesson at this level of physics. I am just a fan of irony.

The explanation is right: find the wikipedia p. about "thermal effusivity".
Th. eff. is derived from the rate of exchange of heat, and it can be used to find the actual temp you "feel" from touching an object!
The effusivity of a metal is much higher than that of a human, which is much higher than that of paper.
So the temperature you feel when touching a metal is closer to the temp. of the metal, whereas when you touch paper, the temperature you feel is much closer to your own temperature!

This is wrong, the heat radiates in Infrared waves and doesnt require particules to go away. Actually, the heat in space dissipates way faster. It's really easy to lose heat, on earth, you limit the losses because 1) the air is a good insulator and 2) everything around you radiates IR. So in space, you'll lose your heat way faster. Aluminium's massic heat will make it so that it needs a different amount of joules to raise 1 degree centigrade than the plastic.

For example, one matter could take 1600 joules out of your hand to raise its temperature by 1 degree, whereas the other would take 2 joules for the same, thus feeling cold or hot!

So, if you start with the two objects when they are at the same temperature, one will gain energy (heat) faster than the other. The metals have the lower specific heat and require less energy to raise/lower the temperature. Imagine on a hot day leaving the book and the metal out in the sun- the metal absorbs heat energy better, and feels hotter, and transfers that heat to your more efficiently than the book, even though they both feel warm, the metal transfers the heat better than the book.

Objects have specific heats, and that's the amount of energy required to change the temperature of the object 1°C or 1K. Metals have very low specific heat, so they change temperature rapidly. Water has a high specific heat, so it is often used as a thermal insulator because it maintains its temperature longer due to the fact that it requires more energy to raise water's temperature.

Put simply, you could say that temperature tries to become equal. 
Put a cold and a warm object together and the warm object will get colder and the cold object will get warmer.
Your question focuses on "heat", thus it will go from the warmer object to the colder object. Flip it and ask about "cold" and the answer would be that cold goes towards the warm object. That's basically why it's called "Thermal" and not "heat" conductivity.

Let's see, an average book contains 80,000 words. An average word is 5 letters, or "characters". A character is stored in a byte by ASCII standard. 80000(words)*5(chars per word) = 400000 chars, or bytes.

400000/1000 = 400 kb, which is almost half a MB. Therefore 2 books can be stored in a whole megabyte. 1000 MB = 1 GB, and an average HDD is 250 GB.

2(books per megabyte)*1000(Megabytes) = 2000 books in 1 GB, 2000 * 250GB = 500000. 500,000 books could fit in an average HDD.

500,000 > 1

Yes, but for a different reason. Since the body does not actively cool very much, it wouldn't feel warmer because of the same explanation. It would feel warmer because aluminum will draw out the heat from the center of the block a lot faster than plastic. With a plastic block, the outside will cool off fairly quickly, but the inside will still be piping hot. With aluminum, The heat from the inside is transferred to the outside much quicker, so the outside stays hot until the inside cools down.

Your fingers measure temperature, not heat flow.  The book and the plastic *are* warmer, because when you touch them, your hand warms them up. The size of atoms themselves does not have anything to do with specific heat, though. If size did have a positive correlation with thermal conductivity, then silicon or phosphorous would conduct heat better than aluminum and thus, feel colder to the touch. But such is not the case. As far as I know, thermal conductivity and specific heat have to do with the arrangement of atoms in a molecule, and the arrangement of molecules with each other.

To think of it another way, consider sleeping in the wilderness. Your body needs to know where it can lay down for a long period without losing all its body heat. If you touch a thermal insulator, your body lets you know that you can remain in contact with that object for a long time without losing too much heat.

Heat energy transfers from a body with a higher temperature to a lower one if work is not involved (VERY simplified version of the second law of thermodynamics). Both the metal and the book have a lower temperature than the human body. Therefore, heat transfers from the hand to the "colder" object.

Thermal conductivity is higher in the metal than the book. Therefore, heat is being transferred quicker into the metal than the book. "Cold" is heat leaving the body.

I know why you say "Transfer of Heat."  It does reduce confusion.  However, Heat is defined as "the energy transferred from one system to another by thermal interaction."  And so the "heat" actually is the transfer of energy, and so to say "transfer of heat" actually has no literal meaning.  It is energy that is being transferred, not heat.

All he is trying to say is that our PERCEPTION of temperature has to do with how our brain interprets our body’s loss or gain of heat. With the aluminium, heat was being transferred away from the hands faster than the rubber. Our brain senses the faster loss of heat with the aluminium and puts it into something we can PERCEIVE (i.e. a cold object). The rubber doesn’t let the heat from our hands move much and our brain then interprets that as warmer as the heat is being retained.

aluminium feels colder than the book/plastic so many people will think that the aluminium is colder. However, we see that the ice cube melts faster on the aluminium than on the plastic. This is because the heat from the person holding the aluminium is conducted through the plate to the cube better than the plastic as metal is a better conductor of heat. When we feel the aluminium, it feels cold because it conducts heat away from our hand, because it is a good conductor, not because it is cold.

At that point, you need to define what you mean by heat. Temperature is just a measure of the motion of the particles in an object. The more they move, the higher its temperature (roughly speaking). So particles in the warmer body are moving all around whereas particles in the cooler body are closer to being at rest. Particles in the warmer body collide with the ones in the cooler body, putting them in motion and thereby increasing the cooler body's temperature.

Temperature is essentially the average kinetic energy of all particles in a substance. The higher the temperature, the more the particles jiggle about. Heat is conducted because on the hot side there is more movement than on the cold side and so the hotter particles make the colder particles move more until they're all just as hot. Metals are good thermal conductors because they've got free electrons which can easily be moved or stopped in their structure.

I have a question about temperature scales.
For Celcius and Farenheit, we use the word 'degree', because it's a relative scale (i.e., has a zero, negative and positive values).
Kelvin doesn't use the word 'degree' because it's an absolute scale, i.e. only has zero and positive values, no negative.
So how come the same logic isn't applied to the Rankine scale? Or is there another reason why the word 'degree' isn't used for Kelvins?

So the black one absorbs all the wavelengths. And wavelengths = energy. So black surfaces are more warm then white ones

Light from the sun consists of a band of wavelengths of light. Different wavelengths of light are different levels of energy. Second thing you should know is that colors are reflections of certain wavelengths of light. e.g. the color red has a wavelength of almost 620nm. So a surface that is appears red, reflects the wavelengths 620nm. A white surface reflects all colors/wavelengths and a black surface doesn't reflect any.

Dark colors absorb more heat. It's also the same reason why you shouldn't get a black car, because in the summer it would be hotter (when you leave your car in the sun your car gets hot) then a white one, ect.
